question: https://www.quora.com/Can-we-manipulate-physics-laws-in-the-future-with-our-advanced-technology

Answer: Which is the most used physics law that is likely to be broken in the near future?Here’s the thing: Laws of physics that are heavily used are very unlikely to be broken in the near future, simply because they’ve already been heavily tested.At best, you’ll find out that the law works just fine over the vast majority of cases, and you need a really extreme condition like a neutron star to have a situation that the law in question doesn’t work totally accurately.For example… Newton came up with his law of gravity. And several centuries later, Einstein came out with general relativity, which handlWhich is the most used physics law that is likely to be broken in the near future?Here’s the thing: Laws of physics that are heavily used are very unlikely to be broken in the near future, simply because they’ve already been heavily tested.At best, you’ll find out that the law works just fine over the vast majority of cases, and you need a really extreme condition like a neutron star to have a situation that the law in question doesn’t work totally accurately.For example… Newton came up with his law of gravity. And several centuries later, Einstein came out with general relativity, which handled a bunch of extreme situations.Let’s look at how “broken” Newton’s law of gravity was. It predicted that planets would orbit the sun in elliptical orbits. It also predicted that these orbits could precess slightly due to gravitational pulls from other planets.So that orbit is precessing by close to 15 degrees per orbit.And astronomers measure the precession of Mercury’s orbit, added in the gravities of all the other planets - and came up 43 arc second short. How big is that?Pick up a pencil or pen, hold it up at arm’s length. Its width is (roughly) a half degree or 30 arc minutes (60 minutes to the degree). So imagine 1/30th of that width for 1 arc minute. We’re going to split that 60 ways to make arc seconds. We’ll round 43 to 45, so Newton’s law was wrong by 3/4th of 1/30th of the width of a pencil at arm’s length.Oh, did I mention that’s not per orbit, but *per century*, or 400+ orbits? So per orbit it’s 1/400th of 3/4th of 1/30th of the width of a pencil at arm’s length.So does that mean that Newton’s law of gravity was broken by Einstein? No, it was simply amended for certain extreme situations.

Answer: The laws of physics are not laws in the sense of crime and punishment. What we call the laws of physics are representations of the fundamental properties of the universe. Our understanding of these properties may improve over time, but there no laws to “break".

Answer: The wild west nature of the internet ended.At the start of the decade the internet was still cleaved from the real world. It wasn’t considered the public square that it is today. It was closer to notes passed in class, or dirty jokes told in bedrooms. It was yours.Before 2010, the web was indeed a space, but a special pseudo space for sharing silly things, playing games, downloading free media andThe wild west nature of the internet ended.At the start of the decade the internet was still cleaved from the real world. It wasn’t considered the public square that it is today. It was closer to notes passed in class, or dirty jokes told in bedrooms. It was yours.Before 2010, the web was indeed a space, but a special pseudo space for sharing silly things, playing games, downloading free media and communicating frivolously. There was a clear disconnect between the web, which was not real, and say, cable news or the cafeteria, which was real. Communication and activity online felt closer to the diagetic world of a video game or movie. If bad things happened there, bad things didn’t “really” happen, anymore than killing an NPC in an RPG was really a murder. You chatted to other people or read about whatever, with virtually no filter or sense of broader consequence.Even the concept of people outside your closest circles reading your messages wasn’t taken seriously. Interpreting your social media posts as some sort of official opinion or statement wasn’t even conceptualized. The internet was a tool for entertainment and reference with quirky communication channels built in. It was a playpen for nonsense… lawless and abstract. Major cultural players like governments and corporations simply weren’t involved very much. Do you even recall the fact that there were no ads on Youtube outside of the banners on the bottom 6th of the frame?On the contrary, the flow of political revolution and international scandal online has now become a routine part of our daily lives. People are held accountable for a Facebook post as if it’s a personal press release. The president does a non-zero amount of his official communication on Twitter. If you’re old enough to remember, try and imagine George Bush’s Myspace posts threatening war with the Persians… I can’t either.Around 2010, the mainstream consolidation started happening. Facebook messages and embarrassing social media posts started popping up in political punditry. The AOL-style banners were replaced by television-style car commercials running before videos. Major corporations actually sunk major resource...

With age, it seems, one is better able to distinguish between things that slowly change, human nature for instance, and things that move fast, like technology.Both culture and technology have advanced very significantly over the past 20 years.In “culture” it is no longer appropriate to abuse women, for instance. New forms of artistic expression are being tried out, which in itself is nothing new, BTW.Technology has advanced to a point where the majority of people on the globe are networked. Just have a peek at the war in Ukraine - Starlink changes the way wars are fought in ways unimaginable (or at least unfeasible) 20 years ago. $ 120 today buys you a smartphone that has an order of magnitude more computing power than the most expensive personal computer 20 years ago.Astronomy and medical science have made huge leaps over the past 20 years.Energy production is changing rapidly as we speak. So is the automotive industry.Society hasn’t stagnated either. Some changes are not positive, like the upward distribution of wealth. Others are very positive, namely the recognition of the fundamental rights of LBGTQI+ people.You may want to change your perspective or the way you lead your life if you want to feel the changes in society. Unfortunately, sitting at home, watching TV and walking the dog are activities that may be nice, but they do not make you feel the changes in society.

Answer: We have a lot of technology related to robotics running parallel to each other at the moment to produce the elements leading to the perfect android.We have robots that have sensitivity grips on the fingers that allow for measured grips of tension allowing the robot hand to grip difficult and fragile objects.At the moment the chief area for this level of use is in the area of replacement limbs for people who have either lost their hands or have inadequately developed limbs.We have robots specifically designed to walk, climb stairs and dance (because that’s a thing) and at the moment the real isWe have a lot of technology related to robotics running parallel to each other at the moment to produce the elements leading to the perfect android.We have robots that have sensitivity grips on the fingers that allow for measured grips of tension allowing the robot hand to grip difficult and fragile objects.At the moment the chief area for this level of use is in the area of replacement limbs for people who have either lost their hands or have inadequately developed limbs.We have robots specifically designed to walk, climb stairs and dance (because that’s a thing) and at the moment the real issue for these robots is their sheer expensive requirements .. they are not cheap or really utility yet.ASIMO robot by HondaTop speed at this stage is a whopping 5.6km an hour .. it can be used to get your newspaper, but then, so can your dog at a much reduced price.We also have people working exclusively on the attempt to render a more realistic and functional human-looking robot, where the focus is on making the robot’s reactions and facial expressions, skin tone and character as realistic as possible.This is actually a lot harder than it sounds because the human being is geared to recognize not only accurate human body language signals, but FALSE human body language signals. If you dont fake it extremely well, a human being not only can discern the difference, it makes the human feel uncomfortable or lied to about its true nature.Then we have the stuff that comes out of Boston Dynamics which is genuinely insanely creative and breakthrough.They work on four feet for stability but they are able to navigate all sorts of terrain and make graded judgements on territory and establish new paths when the current path is unsatisfactory. Sure they dont have a human representation but they are functionally stable, work in multiple areas and have enough sensor data crunched that they can accurately work their landscape.These are all different aspects of the current field of robotics, where one specialises in realism another specialises in sensitivity, another specialises on interaction, another works on environment and traction on multiple surfaces.The pieces are all being built in parallel but have yet to unite as a single unit.What will bring them together?Eventually a medium and a set of standards will be created to unite all robot parts for usage and create a series of interlinkable protocols that can be used to build separate robot parts that work together.It may take a single company making such a breakthrough that not only does the robot outpace its opponents, it outsells them in relation to demand.

Hollywood robots look like humans. Real robots look like this:And this:And this:As they become more advanced, they’ll look different from the above, but there’s no reason for real, actual robots to look like humans and for the most part they don’t. Some AI researches like to create robots with faces on them because they are supposed to interact with humans but there’s no real point to putting them in purely human-looking bodies. The military is experimenting with robots that are basically humanoid but that’s so they can fit through human doorways, go down human hallways and murder humans. But the bots the military is designing that don’t have murderous intent look more like rats and dogs — the better to scout a situation without being bleeding obvious about it, or investigate wreckage to uncover survivors, that sort of thing.

Answer: The early Americans were basically at the same technological level as the Egyptians during the age of the Pharaohs. There were a number of reasons for this, mostly related to resources not available on the continent.The first of these is Tin. Copper was plentiful and frequently refined and used but copper is too soft to make effective tools beyond needles or wire(both of which were known). Copper is too soft to hold an edge or act as a lever. When alloyed with tin Bronze is formed and it is strong enough to make useful tools. There are(were) a number of rich tin deposits in Europe and China, bThe early Americans were basically at the same technological level as the Egyptians during the age of the Pharaohs. There were a number of reasons for this, mostly related to resources not available on the continent.The first of these is Tin. Copper was plentiful and frequently refined and used but copper is too soft to make effective tools beyond needles or wire(both of which were known). Copper is too soft to hold an edge or act as a lever. When alloyed with tin Bronze is formed and it is strong enough to make useful tools. There are(were) a number of rich tin deposits in Europe and China, but none in the Americas. Without Bronze Copper, Silver and Gold, the other easily refined metals are largely decorative. Iron smelting likely derives from accidentally using iron ores to construct ovens for refining other metals.Contrary to popular belief the First Nations were quite aware of the wheel, they simply lacked draft animals to make using it for transportation worth while. Llamas were the closest thing to a draft animal in the Americas, and they cannot carry significantly more than a man, and you need a man to supervise them. Also, a Human porter is much better at following directions and can use narrow footpaths and climb stairs. A cart requires wide roads and gentle slopes. Building a road over a mountain means moving a lot of dirt, getting the same load over with a bunch of porters requires, at most, a native guide. Large objects like building stones were moved in the Egyptian manner, with ropes, levers, rollers, and lots of muscle.Mayan and Aztec astronomy and calendars were superior to those of the conquistadors, in that they accounted for leap years and precession of the equinox more elegantly. Canoes and kayaks are faster, more maneuverable, of shallower draft and lighter to portage than the clinker built small boats of the invaders. First nations people understood the use of fertilizer and crop rotation to preserve soil fertility better than the Europeans who used dung, often leading to the spread of disease.

Answer: If we want to know why the Native Americans were less technologically advanced than Europeans and Asians, we have to understand what made the Eastern Hemisphere more advanced in the first place.The first civilisations were centred around the Tigris and Euphrates rivers in Ancient Mesopotamia along with the Nile River in Egypt.These cities were built because the populations were centred along these rivers because food production can only happen along these rivers.These civilisations needed better tools, irrigation systems, and animals to help do the work as well.These served as hearths that sprIf we want to know why the Native Americans were less technologically advanced than Europeans and Asians, we have to understand what made the Eastern Hemisphere more advanced in the first place.The first civilisations were centred around the Tigris and Euphrates rivers in Ancient Mesopotamia along with the Nile River in Egypt.These cities were built because the populations were centred along these rivers because food production can only happen along these rivers.These civilisations needed better tools, irrigation systems, and animals to help do the work as well.These served as hearths that spread westwards to the Mediterranean Sea, and eastwards to the Indus River valley.China, while not desert, needed wet fields to help with the production of Rice, which required swamp-like conditions to grow.Meanwhile in Southeast Asia, humans discovered the breeding potential of Chickens.In South Asia and Europe, cows were made useful for their production of milk.When Horses had left the Eurasian Steppes, their ability to travel had increased the speed of communication.However, diseases like the Flu and Smallpox originate from these animals.Now let’s look at the Americas.The first problems arise from the lack of animals to domesticate.You can try to capture deer, but they can just jump over any useful fencing.You can try to capture a buffalo, but it can just charge down any fencing.So in most of the Americas, it was far easier to hunt down these animals rather than wasting resources to create adequate ways to contain them.The only animal that was domesticated before European arrival were LLAMAS! (and alpacas and dogs too)They were a major reason for the Incan civilisation as they can travel throughout the mountains. Though riding Llamas is impossible and can only carry materials via caravan.Second, regarding agriculture, the Incans and Aztecs had created terraces for potatoes and chiampas for corn respectively.But outside of these areas, most agriculture was small scale, similar to non-Roman Europe.The lack of useful animals also created less diseases native to the Americas.Even if there were major viruses, the less enclosed housing of the Native Americans meant that viruses could never reach plague levels, and usually died out.The only disease to have its origins in the Western hemisphere is Syphilis.It was these factors that gave Europe and Asia the advantage when it came to the age of exploration.
